name: Scholarly Depth
description: 30 erudite words for serious readers and intellectuals

words.definition: Having a ready insight into and understanding of things.
examples: The perspicacious analyst predicted the trend.
Her perspicacious observations impressed everyone.

words.definition: Looking or sounding sad and dismal.
examples: The lugubrious music matched the funeral mood.
His lugubrious expression worried friends.

words.definition: The appearance of being true or real.
examples: The novel's verisimilitude made it feel authentic.
Historical films strive for verisimilitude.

words.definition: Showing a lack of courage or determination; timid.
examples: The pusillanimous leader refused to act.
His pusillanimous response disappointed everyone.

words.definition: Excessively flattering or ingratiating.
examples: His unctuous praise rang false.
The unctuous salesman made her uncomfortable.

words.definition: Having a sharp and critical quality; biting.
examples: Her mordant wit was legendary.
The mordant review devastated the playwright.

words.definition: Vigorous and articulate; effective and penetrating.
examples: His trenchant analysis exposed the flaws.
She made trenchant criticisms of the policy.

words.definition: Translucently clear; easily understood.
examples: The pellucid water revealed the bottom.
Her pellucid prose made complex ideas accessible.

words.definition: Clear and transparent; easily understood.
examples: The limpid stream sparkled in sunlight.
His limpid style of writing was refreshing.

words.definition: Difficult to understand; obscure.
examples: The abstruse theory confused most readers.
His abstruse writing limited his audience.

words.definition: Not known about by many people; obscure.
examples: The professor's recondite knowledge impressed scholars.
She studied recondite subjects few understood.

words.definition: The state of being close to someone or something; proximity.
examples: Their propinquity led to friendship.
The propinquity of the buildings created problems.

words.definition: A change of circumstances, typically unwelcome.
examples: Life's vicissitudes made her stronger.
The company weathered many vicissitudes.

words.definition: The quality of having strong moral principles; honesty.
examples: His probity was never questioned.
The position requires complete probity.

words.definition: Morally correct behavior or thinking; righteousness.
examples: She was known for her rectitude.
The organization valued moral rectitude.

words.definition: Excessive confidence or boldness; audacity.
examples: He had the temerity to challenge the CEO.
Her temerity impressed some and shocked others.

words.definition: Insolent or impertinent behavior.
examples: She had the effrontery to demand more.
His effrontery shocked the committee.

words.definition: Composure or coolness under strain.
examples: She handled the crisis with sangfroid.
His sangfroid in emergencies was remarkable.

words.definition: Casual lack of concern; indifference.
examples: His insouciance about deadlines frustrated managers.
She displayed insouciance despite the chaos.

words.definition: A feeling of listlessness and dissatisfaction from lack of interest.
examples: Ennui settled over her during the long afternoon.
The routine job filled him with ennui.

words.definition: The defining spirit or mood of a particular period.
examples: The artist captured the zeitgeist perfectly.
The film reflected the zeitgeist of the decade.

words.definition: Pleasure derived from another's misfortune.
examples: There was an element of schadenfreude in their reaction.
She felt guilty about her schadenfreude.

words.definition: Ridiculously old-fashioned; of the time before the biblical Flood.
examples: His antediluvian views were out of touch.
The antediluvian technology finally failed.

words.definition: Not likely to provoke dissent or offense; inoffensive.
examples: The speech was deliberately anodyne.
His anodyne comments avoided controversy.

words.definition: Tending to induce drowsiness or sleep.
examples: The soporific lecture put students to sleep.
The medicine had a soporific effect.

words.definition: Naive, simplistic, or lacking in substance.
examples: The analysis was jejune and superficial.
Her jejune understanding of politics was evident.

words.definition: Apparently attractive but having no value or integrity.
examples: The meretricious decorations looked cheap.
His meretricious charm fooled no one.

words.definition: Of no value or importance.
examples: The nugatory objections were dismissed.
His contributions were essentially nugatory.

words.definition: Rich in oil; excessively flattering.
examples: His oleaginous manner was off-putting.
The oleaginous politician praised everyone.

words.definition: Eager to argue or fight; aggressively defiant.
examples: The truculent negotiator refused all compromise.
His truculent attitude created conflict.
